title: Cumulative Relative Frequency - AP Statistics Mock Exam
question_text:
Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2017. All rights reserved.

The cumulative relative frequency plot shown above displays fifty AP Statistics mock exam scores.
Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from the graph?

choices.text: If three or higher is considered a qualifying score (passing score), most students did not get a qualifying score on the mock exam.

60
%
of the students scored a four or higher.

About
30
%
of the students scored a three.

100
%
of the students scored a five.

About
70
%
of the students scored higher than a three.

solution:
A cumulative relative frequency is running total of the relative frequencies (
%
of times something happens in a data set). The cumulative relative frequency is the sum of all of the relative frequencies up to that point.

Choice 'E' is correct. Since
30
%
of the students scored three or less, then
70
%
of the students scored higher than a three.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. When observing the data, it looks like we have the coordinate (
2
,
15
%
). This indicates that
25
%
of the scores were two or less, which means that
85
%
of the scores were higher than two. Therefore, most students did receive a qualifying score on the mock exam.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. When observing the data, it looks like we have the coordinate (
4
,
60
%
). This indicates that
60
%
of the students scored a four or less.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. When observing the data, it looks like we have the coordinate (
3
,
30
%
). This indicates that
30
%
of the scores were three or less. We can also observe the coordinate of approximately (
2
,
5
%
). This would indicate that all of the scores could not have been three's, since
5
%
of the scores were two or less.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. The coordinate (
5
,
100
%
) suggests that
100
%
of the students scored five or less.
